author: schone_wizard
content: what exactly do Loopring and Optimism do in terms of optimistic rollups, and how does ETH2 becoming a mothership for rollups on L2 work? or rather what does ETH2 add to the mix that isnt there today? And how is do those two work, without having ETH2 backing in place?

author: protolambda
content: The TLDR is that optimistic rollups use on-chain data, but don't run the computation part unless necessary (someone contests the assumed state root with a fraud proof). This is mostly calldata, no state changes, in the happy case. That already wins you some scaling on Eth1. But if you had more blockspace to put the calldata on, you can have a lot more throughput. Eth2 shards add that extra capacity that so many L2s could use.

author: svantetobias
content: <@!489217181104734219> Just to add to protos answer, Eth2 shards buys us throughput for the price of added friction to cross shard transactions. But if you only need to store data, as L2 rollups mostly do, you can get the added throughput without the downside, which is why the combination is so powerful.

author: chat-bridge
content:
<jadler> To clarify some misconceptions, moving execution off L1 means the L1 consensus needs to do less work for the same number of L1+rollup transactions. However, consensus is not the bottleneck, so this does not mean you can in total execute more transactions. Execution is the bottleneck, therefore the total of L1+one rollup tps must be bounded to ~15 tps worth of work, or you have to sacrifice decentralization to get more tps.
In other words, rollups don't provide scaling, they provide execution sharding.

author: chat-bridge
content:
<jadler> To give some concrete intuitions: imagine Ethereum only did data availability for rollups. You'd be able to process the data throughput of several hundred tps. But would you be able to have a single optimistic rollup with 500 tps without sacrificing decentralization? No, because consensus is not the bottleneck! Users of that rollup still need to run a full node to validate that rollup's txs, and executing those txs is the bottleneck.
However, you could take these 500 tps and split them up into 64 rollups that are bounded to ~15 tps worth of gas.

- 64 15 tps decentralized rollups
